{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2014}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Hugh Dennis | image = Now Show 2005 Hugh Dennis.jpg | imagesize = 240px | caption = Dennis during a radio recording of
''[[The Now Show]]'', 2005 | pseudonym = | birth_name = Peter Hugh Dennis | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1962|02|13|df=y}}{England and Wales Birth Index 1916–2005} | birth_place = [[Kettering]], [[Northamptonshire]], England | medium = [[Stand-up comedy|Stand-up]], [[television]], [[radio]] | nationality = [[England|English]] | active = 1989 – present | genre = [[Political satire]], [[improvisational comedy]], [[insult comedy]] | subject = [[British politics]], [[family]], [[current events]] | spouse = Miranda Carroll (1987–93) Kate Abbot-Anderson (1996–2015; separated) | children = 2 | domesticpartner = [[Claire Skinner]] (2017–) | notable_work = ''[[The Mary Whitehouse Experience]]''
''[[Mock the Week]]''
''[[Outnumbered (UK TV series)|Outnumbered]]''
''[[The Now Show]]''
''[[Not Going Out]]'' | education = [[University College School]] | alma_mater = [[St John's College, Cambridge]] | signature = | footnotes = | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Peter Hugh Dennis''' (born 13 February 1962), known professionally as '''Hugh Dennis''', is an English comedian, actor, writer, [[Impressionist (entertainment)|impressionist]] and [[voice-over artist]], best known for being one half of [[Punt and Dennis]] with comedy partner [[Steve Punt]], and playing Pete Brockman, the father in the [[BBC One]] sitcom ''[[Outnumbered (UK TV series)|Outnumbered]]''. Since 2005, Dennis has been a regular panellist on the [[BBC Two]] satirical comedy show ''[[Mock the Week]]''. Since October 2014, Dennis has appeared in the sitcom ''[[Not Going Out]]'' as Toby. He also starred as the narrator in CBBC's The Zoo. ==Early life== Dennis, the younger of two boys, was born in [[Kettering]], [[Northamptonshire]],{{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-1358656/Hugh-Dennis-boring-I-divorced-Ex-wife-reveals-ups-downs-married-Outnumbered-star.html | title=Hugh Dennis was so boring I divorced him: Ex-wife reveals the ups and downs of being married to Outnumbered star | work=[[Daily Mail]] | date=19 February 2011 | accessdate=5 January 2015 | author=Sheridan, Peter}} the son of schoolteacher Dorothy M. (Hinnels) and [[John Dennis (bishop)|John D. Dennis]].{{cite news|title=Hugh Dennis: My family values|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2015/jan/16/hugh-dennis-my-family-values|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=16 January 2015}} His brother, also named John, was the [[List of Ambassadors of the United Kingdom to Angola|British Ambassador to Angola]] from 2014 to 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/change-of-her-majestys-ambassador-to-angola|title=Change of Her Majesty’s Ambassador to Angola|work=GOV.UK|access-date=2018-05-03|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/news/change-of-her-majestys-ambassador-to-angola--2|title=Change of Her Majesty’s Ambassador to Angola|work=GOV.UK|access-date=2018-05-03|language=en}} He grew up in [[Mill Hill]] in [[North London]] as his father was appointed as parish priest of Mill Hill soon after his birth. His father later became the [[Bishop of Knaresborough]] and then of [[Bishop of Saint Edmundsbury and Ipswich|Saint Edmundsbury and Ipswich]].{{cite news|title=Hugh Dennis on working with the kids of Outnumbered|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/showbiz/celebrity-interviews/2009/12/26/hugh-dennis-on-working-with-the-kids-of-outnumbered-86908-21923416/|work=[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]|date=26 December 2009}} Dennis was educated at [[University College School]] in [[London]]. During his time at UCS, he played rugby with [[Will Self]] and was head boy in his final year.{{cite episode|series=Have I Got News for You|series-link=Have I Got News for You|network=[[BBC Two]]|date=25 April 1997|season=13|number=2}} Subsequently, Dennis went on to read for the [[Department of Geography, University of Cambridge|Geography]] [[Tripos]] as an [[Exhibition (scholarship)|exhibitioner]] at [[St John's College, Cambridge|St John's College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]]. His [[Thesis|dissertation]] was titled "The Spatial Distribution of Elementary Education in 19th-century [[Wakefield]]".{{cite news|title=Hugh Dennis: I'm a happy rambler|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2012-02-16/hugh-dennis-i%27m-a-happy-rambler|publisher=[[Radio Times]]|date=16 February 2012}} He also joined the [[Footlights]], where he first met Punt and club president [[Nick Hancock]] and the trio collaborated on a number of projects besides the annual revue.{{cite news|title=In a taxi with...Hugh Dennis|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/you/article-1292798/In-taxi--Hugh-Dennis.html|date=10 July 2010|work=[[Daily Mail]]}} In a 2016 interview with ITV's This Morning Programme, Dennis revealed that he was approached by Britain's domestic intelligence service, MI-5, whilst at Cambridge University and attended a preliminary interview; however, he eventually decided that he did not want to take the matter any further, particularly due to being told during the interview that the job would require him to "do people over".{{Citation|last=This Morning|title=Dara O Briain And Hugh Dennis Talk 150 Episodes Of Mock The Week {{!}} This Morning|date=2016-06-14|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=emuTpAq2-L0|accessdate=2017-07-27}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/home/moslive/article-2152663/Hugh-Dennis-Id-expected-people-Thats-bit-I-uncomfortable-about.html|title='I'd be expected to do people over. That's the bit I was uncomfortable about': How Hugh Dennis turned down MI5 for a life of comedy|work=Mail Online|access-date=2018-05-28}} After graduating with a [[First class honours|first]], Dennis worked for [[Unilever]] for six years in the marketing department while performing comedy with Punt at venues including [[The Comedy Store, London|The Comedy Store]] on the weekends.{{cite news|title=Why Footlights is a breeding ground for double acts|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-11927226|publisher=BBC|date=6 December 2010}}{{cite news|title=In your funnybone rather than your face: Punt and Dennis|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/show-people-in-your-funnybone-rather-than-your-face-punt-and-dennis-1411396.html|work=[[The Independent]]|date=3 July 1994}} The duo then formed half of the team of ''[[The Mary Whitehouse Experience]]'' on [[BBC Radio 1]]. Dennis uses his middle name Hugh as his stage name because [[Equity (trade union)|Equity]] already had a [[Peter Dennis]] when he first started.Hardwick, Viv (7 April 2007). "A headline act". ''The Northern Echo'' (Newsquest North East): p. 26. When the BBC commissioned the series for [[BBC Two]], Dennis took a sabbatical as the rehearsal days changed to weekdays and eventually went into comedy full-time. ==Radio and television career== While an [[Impressionist (entertainment)|impressionist]], Dennis did voices for ''[[Spitting Image]]''{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2004/may/17/broadcasting.uknews|title=Spitting Image plans TV comeback | work=The Guardian | location=London | first=Jason | last=Deans | date=17 May 2004 | accessdate=2010-05-04}} and appeared with Punt as resident support comics on two TV series hosted on the [[BBC]] by [[Jasper Carrott]].{{cite news | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/show-people-in-your-funnybone-rather-than-your-face-punt-and-dennis-1411396.html | location=London | work=The Independent | first=James | last=Rampton | title=Show people: In your funnybone rather than your face: Punt and Dennis | date=3 July 1994}}{{cite news|title=Impressions are back in fashion: The great pretenders|url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2003/sep/30/comedy?INTCMP=SRCH|publisher=[[The Guardian|guardian.co.uk]]|date=30 September 2003}} Dennis also appeared twice as a contestant on the topical panel show ''[[Have I Got News for You]]'', including one opposite former schoolmate Self. Punt and Dennis' radio career includes over a decade of performing ''Punt and Dennis'', ''[[It's Been a Bad Week]]'', ''[[The Party Line (radio)|The Party Line]]'' and the satirical radio comedy show, ''[[The Now Show]]''. On ''[[The Now Show]]'' , Dennis is in a line-up including Punt, [[Mitch Benn]], Laura Shavin, [[Jon Holmes]] and [[Marcus Brigstocke]]. He is friends with [[Chris Morris (satirist)|Chris Morris]] and has had cameos on ''[[Brass Eye]]'' as well as doing the narration for the [[CBBC]] show ''[[Sam & Mark|Sam and Mark's Guide To Dodging Disasters]]''. In December 2009, Dennis joined [[Oz Clarke]] in presenting the sixty minute Christmas special ''[[Oz and Hugh Drink to Christmas]]'' broadcast on [[BBC Two]].{{cite web |author= | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00pk6gy | title=Oz And Hugh Drink To Christmas |work=[[BBC]] |date=20 December 2009 | accessdate=2010-01-05}} In December 2010 the pair returned for a four-part series called ''[[Oz and Hugh Raise the Bar]]'', which puts them in a competition to create a bar featuring only local British food and drinks.{{cite web |author=The BBC | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b00x334f | title=Oz and Hugh Raise the Bar | work=[[BBC]] |date=21 December 2010 | accessdate=2010-12-26}} Dennis has starred in a number of sitcoms, including ''[[My Hero (UK TV series)|My Hero]]'', in which he played obnoxious [[General practitioner|GP]] Piers Crispin. From 2007 to 2014, he starred in ''[[Outnumbered (UK TV series)|Outnumbered]]'', a semi-improvised sitcom based around family life{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2007/08_august/17/outnumbered.shtml|title=Outnumbered Press Pack|work=[[BBC]]|date=17 August 2007|accessdate=2009-12-22}} and won a [[British Academy Television Awards|BAFTA]] nomination in the comedy category for the 2009 Christmas special.{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards-database.html?award=false&category=Television&pageNo=3&year=2009|title=BAFTA Awards 2009|publisher=Bafta.org|accessdate=2014-05-02}} On Radio 4 he also featured in the sitcom ''[[Revolting People]]'' which, like ''Outnumbered'', was co-written by [[Andy Hamilton]]. Besides his regular television work, Dennis is a panellist on ''[[Mock the Week]]'' and has appeared in every episode since its inception. He is a regular guest on various [[BBC]]-broadcast comedy [[panel game show]]s such as ''[[They Think It's All Over (TV series)|They Think It's All Over]]'', ''[[Would I Lie to You? (TV series)|Would I Lie To You?]]'', ''[[QI]]'' and has guest hosted ''[[Have I Got News for You]]''. In 2011, Dennis hosted the short-lived improvisational comedy series ''[[Fast and Loose (TV series)|Fast and Loose]]''. Beginning on 16 February 2012, Dennis and [[Julia Bradbury]] hosted a four-part BBC One documentary series ''The Great British Countryside''. From October 2014, Dennis has started appearing in the sitcom ''[[Not Going Out]]'' as Toby. ==Personal life== Dennis lives in London. In 2015 he separated from his second wife, Catherine ("Kate") Abbot-Anderson, whom he had married in 1996.The mail online 7th July 2016 They have a son, Freddie (born 1997) and a daughter Meg (born 1999).[http://www.findmypast.com/BirthsMarriagesDeaths.jsp Marriages England and Wales 1984–2005] His first marriage to Miranda Carroll ended in divorce in 1993, the pair having married in 1987. In June 2018, it was confirmed Dennis was in a relationship with actress Claire Skinner, who starred opposite him in sitcom Outnumbered.{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/outnumbered-hugh-dennis-claire-skinner-relationship_uk_5b388823e4b0f3c221a18ada|title=‘Outnumbered’ Actor Hugh Dennis Confirms Relationship With On-Screen Wife Claire Skinner|date=2018-07-01|website=HuffPost UK|language=en|access-date=2018-07-01}} In July 2008, Dennis received an [[Honorary degree|Honorary Fellowship]] from the [[University of Northampton]].[http://www.northampton.ac.uk/news/release/?id=UON8251 Hugh Dennis welcomed to The University of Northampton] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080718080458/http://www.northampton.ac.uk/news/release/?id=UON8251 |date=18 July 2008 }} Northampton.ac.uk Dennis took part in the 2007 [[L'Étape du Tour]], cycling an open stage of the [[Tour de France]] for amateurs which was held in the mountains 2 weeks before the main event. This was discussed in the fifth series of ''[[Mock the Week]]'' and also ''[[QI]]'' series six, episode 5 'France'. He started in 2,400th place of 8,000 entrants, finishing in 3,400th from 4,000 who completed it, five hours behind the winner. In October 2011, Dennis completed the Great South Run in Portsmouth for the Alzheimers Society.{{citation needed |date=June 2016}} Dennis was the subject of the [[BBC One]] programme ''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (UK TV series)|Who Do You Think You Are?]]'' (broadcast on 12 September 2012) in which he tries to find out more about his two grandfathers and their backgrounds.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01mmlx5 "Hugh Dennis"] [[Who Do You Think You Are? (British TV series)|Who Do You Think You Are?]] Episode 5 of 10, Series 9. Broadcast 12 September 2102. His paternal great-grandfather was a miner at [[Kiveton Park Colliery]] near [[Sheffield]] whose younger son, Dennis' grandfather, served as an officer during [[World War I]], and was coincidentally trained at Dennis' ''alma mater'' [[St John's College, Cambridge|St John's College]]. His maternal grandfather also served in France during the Great War and was in the [[Suffolk Regiment]]. Dennis has one brother, John David Dennis, who is a career diplomat, currently serving as the British Ambassador to [[Angola]].[https://www.gov.uk/government/news/change-of-her-majestys-ambassador-to-angola UK Foreign and Commonwealth Office: News] 19 September 2013. Hugh Dennis is a supporter of [[Arsenal F.C.]].http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2013-06-16/hugh-dennis-on-being-a-complete-idiot-around-hugh-laurie Dennis is a Fellowhttp://www.rgs.org/AboutUs/Our+members.htm of the [[Royal Geographical Society]]. ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- !
